touched you know touch databases in that time it was always sequel
then in 2001 so this very year i got a job at mongodb as a developer advocate

is kind of cool you know i got a job somewhere that i hadn't used their products much but we'll get on to that but it's all been
great fun and this talk is all about the journey i took where i really had to change my
mindset from relational tabular databases to document databases and you
know as you can imagine in six months it's been quite a whirlwind and i thought it'd make quite a good talk and i'd share it with you

cannot change anything so you know it's important to you know open your mind to try new things and

differences in the terms and concepts between relational databases and document databases
then we'll learn about why document databases such as mongodb are such a great fit for modern application
development and then we'll talk about how mongodb and net work together
and how we how easy it is to get started in literally a few lines of code and then finally we'll look at some of

beyond just the ones you get in json such as dates arrays and objects
but a document starts off with you know two curly braces if you've used
the c language of family family see family of languages before such as c sharp c plus plus go php
javascript you know not javascript json objects is pretty familiar to you you've got the curly braces
and then you've got their field value pairs you might see the fields referred to as a key an attribute a property but
it's all the same thing and this is all fine in theory but let's look an example

and his work you know what what would that look like in a relational database world and what would that look like as a
document database well the first thing to think about of
course is that well i'm a client of phil's so the first thing phil's going to have is clients and in a traditional
database world you might store that in a table called clients so we'd have different our columns for
our properties so we've got an id which would tend to be the column with
unique values it would call the primary key then you've got things like name number of sessions a week and a phone

cool just one table some information but how would that look in a document

you've got these field value pairs with the fields being surrounded by double quotes now you can see here our id is called
underscore id in mongodb documents you have you have this idea of a of
an id but it's always called underscore id and it's a special object id field that we'll see later on
but you have again it has to be you know it's always unique and we have this underscore id and then the other fields that we'd expect
cool but then you know we've got these clients but then
things get more interesting because well you get you got things about a client but that's maybe not the only
information that phil cares about i know for me when i started at the gym one of the things i had
was goals i had goals of things i wanted to achieve these these are the reasons why i joined the gym and these are actually
completely genuine run five kilometers ticks uh build muscle well my uh deadlifting
personal best is 120 kilos so yeah we're good for building muscle and complete a pull-up we're not there
yet but we'll get there maybe you never know maybe this time next year i'll be back and i can tell
you that i did it but you know as you can see with with relational databases even though this data is related it's stored in separate
tables because one one client might have multiple goals and so trying to replicate like
represent that in one table in the client's table would be quite difficult so you've got goals and then obviously
where where relational databases get their name from is that tables have relationships between them so you can
see here we've got the we've got an id column for goals which again is a unique primary key column but we've also got a
client id column which maps to the clients table so we can then say okay well we've got these goals in this goals
table and they're mapped to this client so then when you want to start using them you then have to start doing
expensive joins but in a document database you don't need to do that
and mongodb we have this saying which i've heard multiple times but it makes complete sense which is
data that's accessed together should be stored together you know there's why why keep it separate you know if you're going to be
accessing it together because you know goals make no sense without a client attached to them and a client maybe they
don't have goals but let's be honest if you're signing up to the gym you probably do even if you don't realize it
and so we can store things together and this is where the power of the of a bison document comes in because we've
got this array here of goals and it's just an array of strings so we can just say create this array in this document
it just says for the goals this is what they are and you can have one goal you can have 50 goals it doesn't matter it
can all be stored together so we have our clients and we have our goals but in order to achieve a goal
you've actually got to do well exercise so what happens each week is
phil will give me we'll you know have a have her planned out roughly an exercise plan for the day
and i get him to actually text me every week what we did so i get an idea of you know what the exercise was whether if it
was if it involved you know a dumbbell or a kettlebell what the weight was and so you know if this is a relational
database you might have an exercises table that would record you know the idea of the exercise
again the client id because it's you know it's the exercises for a specific client the name of the exercise but then sets
and reps because you know you need to know how many times you're going to do something but also how many times you can repeat
that cycle but we can take advantage in documents of how much easier it is you know again
data that's accessed together should be stored together so because we've got the power of bs on
we can store an array of objects so we can have an object for each exercise so
we've got the name of the exercise the sets and the reps grouped together because it makes sense they're inside an
object because a rep makes no sense without a number of uh sets you know a name of an exercise means
nothing without the number of sets and reps you've got to do so it's stored together in an object nice and simple
but of course i'm not going to be phil's only client phil is an extremely hard working
individual not only does he have a lot of clients but he's just completed training as a police officer so you know he
never never sits still i don't know how he does it but you know he's got other clients and actually i met phil because
a friend of mine introduced me to him and her name is chris but chris is a very private person so
you know we can store the information in the client's table such as you know name and number of sessions she has a week
but she doesn't like sharing her phone number you know that her and phil communicate in other ways like instagram or email
but that doesn't store a phone number now you know in in relational databases
you you know they try and encourage you not to have a null a null can mean two things anyway it can either mean
i don't have this information or i don't know what it is yet yeah and so null can be quite difficult
to handle but one of the great things about document databases is that you've
actually got especially with mongodb document databases is that the schema is actually flexible
it's okay that chris doesn't want to share her phone number we just don't add that field in the document perfectly
valid still work just don't include it and you know that's great nothing's going to break
you just if you don't know what if you don't want to include it don't if you want to add feel you know if chris wanted to add her email address or phil

and again we can just populate our you know populate this information again chris has goals and exercises as

to go hey i want to make a change this database can you take it offline change this to you know change this for

while you make these changes but because the scheme is flexible doesn't matter don't need to do that
you've got high availability as i said you've also got flexibility

that bit difficult to keep but that's okay the scheme is with with mongodb it's flexible that's fine it
handles it nothing's gonna break there's no down time you just carry on
and it can also be scaled vertically if you you know if you find that your
your business or whatever it is or your project is suddenly taking off and you've got loads and loads and loads of people coming to your
coming to your website or your application and suddenly you know the server's
struggling a little bit that's okay it can scale vertically just add some extra resources whether it's a ram or some
more hard drive space and it will just carry on on its merry way you know just keep walking or as
they say in finding nemo keep on swimming but one advantage wrong way but one
advantage that it has over relational databases is horizontal scaling
so rather than having to spend a fortune on extra resources because let's be honest
parts can get quite expensive especially once you need more and more and more so you can scale horizontally which means
rather than having you know adding more resources you just have more of them so mongodb stores your data in what it
calls clusters or replica sets and you can just have multiple replica sets if you need you know if if one or two is
not enough have six have ten have a hundred whatever you need the other great thing as well is that
you can also do something called sharding which if you ever think of it like going to the library you go to the
library and you know you see things broken up into maybe a to d and e to h and so on
and so you go and you go right okay i need to find this book and it's going to be in this section so i'll go there to get it and it's the same as sharding it
will break your if you've got a large data set it will break it up into into little pieces that you define
to then you know spread it around whether it's like more of them or globally closer to your users and it
will it will just make your life easier so it'll be much higher performance because things in your large data set have been broken down
so again if your business takes off that's okay you can just scale horizontally and it will cope with it just fine
